title: Glyph-Love
content:
Inspired by something Ole just wrote, I figured to ask this trivial little question:   
   
What's the glyph you most love?   
   
If you're a type designer, please choose one you've made. Here's mine:   
 ![Brutaal_g](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142917im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/29263.gif)

very nice G

Since I have to choose one of my own, I choose this:   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142917im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/29323.gif)   
   
Choosing one that I actually still like has been a humbling experience. I guess my best work is yet to come...

\> This is an impossible task.   
   
You just haven't met the right glyph yet. ;-)   
   
hhp

I'm quite happy with this one from an upcoming design tentatively called Curio.   
   
 ![Curio � Grant Hutchinson](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142917im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/29336.gif)

This is difficult, but favourite among my own designs is probably the lowercase alpha from Clio:   
   
 ![Clio Greek alpha](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142917im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/32091.gif)   
   
Picking a favourite glyph designed by someone else might be even more difficult, but Giovanni Mardersteig's Dante family deserves mention for containing _two_ glyphs I really love: the lowercase roman a and the lowercase italic g.   
   
Here's an even more difficult question: what is your favourite whitespace between two glyphs that you have designed?

Hey, that alpha is pretty sexy.   
   
\> your favourite whitespace between two glyphs   
   
Now you're getting really esoteric! :-)   
I haven't designed any notable whitespace yet. But I remember once seeing an "ft" space that was amazing - I forget where.   
   
hhp

![Ets](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142917im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/32100.gif)   
The ampersand from Oneleigh Italic (left) was inspired by, among other things, the Monotype Garamond ampersand (right), something Les Usherwood once said about the ampersand beign a character he liked to get his teeth into (or words to that effect), and of course all those pages people used to put together showing ampersands from a variety of fonts.
